creator.name: Joe Brewer
creator.bio: I am a change strategist working on behalf of humanity, and also a complexity researcher, cognitive scientist, and evangelist for the field of culture design.

paragraphs.name: dcd5
paragraphs.text: Struggling to Feel Human in These Times

paragraphs.name: 0fb5
paragraphs.text: Now, more than ever, we need to hold strong to our humanity.

paragraphs.name: 80aa
paragraphs.text: Simply being human in today’s world is a very hard thing to do. The sheer scale and pace of change is overwhelming.

paragraphs.name: 6da0
paragraphs.text: Every day there is a new controversy trending on Facebook and Twitter. Each week a new crisis to contend with. All around us are the signals that we are trying to connect with too many people, finding ourselves spread too thin, and feeling a lack of grounding in ourselves as we confront the many disruptions in our lives.

paragraphs.name: 16cf
paragraphs.text: I have been feeling this way throughout the year — as I’ve been writing regular articles, coordinating numerous projects, hosting conversations on my social media feeds, and generally trying to get along in life while I do all these things.

paragraphs.name: 726d
paragraphs.text: And all of it has come into sharp relief when my wife became pregnant earlier this year. This was something we’ve been planning for a long time, so it didn’t come as a surprise. But now that we are five months into the pregnancy I am feeling the disorientation of not being able to act like a human being because the world around me is so full of tasks to manage and fires to put out.

paragraphs.name: bbde
paragraphs.text: The reflection I want to explore with all of you is why it’s so hard to simply be human in the world today. This is something I find to be profound at a deeply personal level. How is it that I can feel so much inspiration and joy watching my wife’s body go through the changes? As we hear the first heartbeat on the ultrasound? Feel the first kick in the womb? And relive memories from our own childhoods as we ponder what the future holds in store for this precious new life that has yet to arrive?

paragraphs.name: e935
paragraphs.text: All the while, in the midst of this incredible journey, I find the time to host dialogue with the roughly 3,500 “friends” in my Facebook network and seed the birth of two new fields — that of cultural evolution in the research world and culture design for tackling the global challenges my child will live through in his or her lifetime.

paragraphs.name: ff39
paragraphs.text: My own parents both passed away five years ago. Mom was taken by cancer. Dad was lost to a massive stroke. So I am left to carry their emotional markers in my body as I go through the alchemy of becoming a father myself. I cannot call them to hear their voice. Share with them what it means to become a parent. Or ask for their guidance along the way.

paragraphs.name: f182
paragraphs.text: In parallel with this deep change in myself, I keep looking into the shadowy future of planetary-scale climate catastrophe and the harms arising from the political polarizations sparking violence and bigotry among different ideological camps at home and abroad. My eyes wide open to the history of poverty and inequality, knowing how systemic corruption was created by design to produce outcomes like these for the hoarding of wealth and power by a tiny few.

paragraphs.name: 8b3e
paragraphs.text: I look down at my wife’s belly and think about how important it is to hold the ambivalence of sobriety and fear alongside inspiration and joy. This paradox is the routine existence of every person alive today.

Human beings did not evolve in this kind of world. Our ancestors lived out their lives in small nomadic bands — only interacting with a few hundred people in the entirety of their existence. Imagine it. Only talking to a few hundred people in the expanse of time between cradle and grave. Yet now we see millions, even billions, of human beings going through the choreographed motions of modern life every single day.

paragraphs.name: 363b
paragraphs.text: Our civilizations (all of them) arose within a rare period of stability in the history of the Earth. This “Holocene” moment spans from the end of the last ice age some 10,000 years ago to the dawn of the industrial era — which has now officially been dubbed the “Anthropocene” or Age of Humans by geologists — because our collective actions are leaving an imprint on the planet that will be measurable millions of years into the future.

paragraphs.name: 27c9
paragraphs.text: What does it mean to birth a child in the Age of Humans? How are we supposed to feel about this? I grapple daily with the demands on my time in a society that treats humans as nothing more than cogs in the machinery of late-stage capitalism. We are meant to feel pressured to produce in the name of efficiency and productivity. All the while, my friends are geographically dispersed too far away to sit with around a fire and share stories about the unfolding of our lives.

This inability to act like humans is an exceedingly difficult burden to carry. Yet each of us must navigate the global changes in our own way for the continued existence of our species. We must recover our basic humanity to make it through the crucibles of change that are closing in around us. This means carving out time to just be with one another. Hold space for reflection. Have conversations that matter. Feel human contact. Love and be loved.

paragraphs.name: 6d76
paragraphs.text: We must remember to practice our nomadic ways as tribal groups where everyone knows everyone else and the loyalty bonds run deep.

paragraphs.name: e52a
paragraphs.text: Remember that to be human is to be profoundly social. We literally cannot survive without one another. This fact is unquestionable for the unborn child feeding off the blood supply of the woman I love. It will continue to be obviously true throughout the vulnerabilities of his or her childhood and adolescence for many years to come.

paragraphs.name: 47f9
paragraphs.text: The great technologies we have created mask the profound interdependence we humans have with each other. Now that we all — the full 7.4 billion people on Earth — are on a crash course with a new geologic age, we must hold firm to the ancient roots that carried our ancestors forth through so many changes for millennia before we were born.

Let us find our humanity. Be in it and flourish. For this is how we will survive the changes. And how our grandchildren will carry forth for their children to thrive as well. It may be a struggle to feel human in times like these. But this is exactly what we are now called upon to do.

paragraphs.name: 398d
paragraphs.text: Onward, fellow humans.
